newsitem.title: GERMANY: German IBIS DAX index ends two percent lower.
newsitem.headline: German IBIS DAX index ends two percent lower.

text.p: A jittery German market ended the day two percent lower, with sentiment hit by a slide on Wall Street, vague uncertainty about the future of EMU, debt market weakness and impending elections in France.
The IBIS DAX index, which gauges trade in 30 German blue-chips, ended the day down 72.65 points, or two percent, at 3,562.73 points.

Earlier, traders were fearful of what would happen on Wall Street on opening after U.S. chip maker Intel Corp issued a profit warning. Wall St opened lower, but the IBIS DAX recouped some losses later, as the fall had been mostly priced in.

"We're seeing the impact of the whole picture here. We had Intel, there's the EMU uncertainty after the Waigel/Bundesbank row, the elections in France. Also there aren't many people around today, because of the holiday yesterday," a Munich trader said.

Intel said that revenues and net income in its fiscal second quarter would fall below expectations due to weaker-than-projected demand, while athletic footwear and apparel company Nike Inc also issued a profit warning.
The Nike profit warning hit sportswear maker Puma AG particularly hard early on, but the shares came off lows and ended down 2.10 marks, or 3.75 percent, at 52.50 marks.
Its rival Adidas AG also recovered to end down 2.75 marks at 181 marks.
Otherwise, losses in the share market did not really restrict themselves to particular sectors, though some were hit worse than others.
"The chemicals have been hit hard, and the future has come off considerably, which suggests that there is a lot of derivative-led trade out there at the moment," the broker said.
BASF AG ended down 1.10 marks at 62.90 marks, Bayer AG ended down 1.18 marks at 66.90 marks, while Hoechst AG ended down two marks at 66.50 marks.
Other big losers were car stocks BMW AG, which closed down 40 marks at 1,390 marks, while Porsche ended down 129.90 marks at 2,060 marks.
